Episode ends ambiguously but Warner's discovery suggests April's entire story was fabricated.

person_rows.notes: Complex case: JJ's original accusation appears credible (specific birthmark detail, $4M settlement suggesting prior incident), but JJ recants under apparent parental coercion to protect settlement. April's accusation is strongly implied to be fabricated by grandmother Nora, who was revealed to be poisoning April and lying about leukemia. Billy Tripley suffered arrest, perp walk, massive media exposure based primarily on April's fabricated claim (the 'new' victim that strengthened the case after JJ disappeared). The episode's final revelation that Nora fabricated the leukemia and likely the molestation claim suggests Tripley was falsely accused regarding April. During the investigation, several individuals are publicly accused or exposed: Lisa's father Tim Downey is suspected of killing both Lisa and Dr. Tanner; Andy Wall (Lisa's ex-boyfriend) is publicly confronted about domestic violence and the murder; Dr. Derek Tanner is publicly accused of statutory rape and questioned about murder before being killed by Angela Agnelli. Tim Downey is questioned in his workplace/public contexts and threatened by detectives. Andy Wall is publicly confronted at his college study group location.

person_rows.police_conduct_quote: Stabler threatens Tim: 'You're gonna tell me what I wanna know!' and 'You're the one who's gonna be charged... with having sex with his 15-year-old daughter.' Stabler also threatens to 'lock you up' during emotional confrontation.
person_rows.quote_or_scene: Detectives follow Tim to Dr. Tanner's office and publicly confront him about attacking Tanner. Tim found Tanner's body. Later interrogated about both murders. Stabler accuses him: 'You were in his apartment. Your fingerprints were on the doorknob.' Tim: 'I didn't kill Tanner... I didn't shoot him. But I sure as hell wish I did!' Detectives search his truck, car, house for gun. He's treated as primary suspect until cleared.
person_rows.notes: Tim Downey is the victim's father who becomes a murder suspect after his fingerprints are found at Dr. Tanner's murder scene. He discovered Tanner's body after following him. Detectives publicly confront him at Tanner's workplace, threaten him with charges for sex with his daughter (which he didn't do - they mean Tanner did), and interrogate him aggressively. He's subjected to searches and treated as prime suspect for both murders despite being innocent. The public confrontation at the hospital and threats constitute severity 3.

Detectives: 'We hear that you got so worked up when you found out about all the guys she was doing that you smacked her around.' Andy denies hitting or killing Lisa. His alibi with study group is verified. Confrontation occurs in presence of his study group members.
person_rows.notes: Andy Wall is Lisa's ex-boyfriend accused of domestic violence and murder based on Angela's claim he hit Lisa (black eye). He's confronted publicly in front of his college study group. Detectives use aggressive accusations and threats. His alibi is verified - he was studying for exam on Camus' The Stranger with five witnesses. The public nature of the confrontation in front of peers at his study location qualifies as severity 2 exposure.

person_rows.police_conduct_quote: Stabler: 'How'd it feel? How'd it feel screwing a 15-year-old. You like that? You're a liar!' Later: 'You're pathetic.' Stabler physically manhandles him.

Tanner arrested and publicly questioned about statutory rape and murder. He admits sexual relationship with Lisa but claims he didn't know her age and denies murder. His hospital alibi clears him of Lisa's murder. He's later shot and killed by Angela Agnelli, with the detectives' public exposure of him being a contributing factor.
person_rows.notes: Dr. Tanner is guilty of statutory rape (sex with 15-year-old Lisa) but innocent of her murder. Detectives publicly confront him at hospital in front of staff and patients. He's arrested and interrogated. The public exposure leads to Angela Agnelli shooting him to retrieve the sex tape. While he's guilty of the sex crime, the murder accusation was false, and the public exposure contributed to his death. Including because the exposure/investigation created the circumstances leading to his murder. Severity 4 due to death as consequence.

episode_summary.summary: Leon Shragewitz, an observant Jewish butcher, is accused of murdering and dismembering his girlfriend Manette Combs after he witnessed her performing oral sex for money. He is confronted by detectives at his synagogue and arrested, but is later proven innocent when the medical examiner confirms Manette died from a broken neck in a subway fall (accidental death after Leon pushed her). Her body was then stolen from the morgue and dismembered by Russ Bianco for illegal organ trafficking. Leon's public arrest at his synagogue in front of his religious community constitutes exposure, and he was subject to coercive interrogation tactics.

person_rows.notes: Leon is arrested at his synagogue in front of his congregation after being tracked there. He confesses under pressure to accidentally pushing Manette down subway stairs, causing her death, but is proven innocent of the murder/dismemberment he was accused of. The M.E. confirms she died from the fall, and body dismemberment was done post-mortem by Russ Bianco at the morgue. Leon's religious community witnessed his arrest. Detectives used accusatory language and moral condemnation ('she made herself unclean,' 'is that why you killed her') during interrogation. No apology shown.

episode_summary.summary: A sniper kills one child and wounds two others at a public school playground. Initially, detectives suspect a young boy (Johnny Mayhew) who brought his mother's gun to school, but the weapon turns out to be a different caliber. They then arrest an elderly man (Mr. Buggesi) for molesting a witness girl (Maddy), but he was at the dentist during the shooting and did not commit the shooting. The actual shooter is Brannon Lee Redding, a white supremacist skinhead who was given the rifle by Brian Ackerman, leader of a hate group called Revolutionary Aryan Warriors (RAW). The shooting targeted the adopted African-American son of a Rikers corrections officer. Mr. Buggesi is accused publicly and assaulted by Maddy's uncle before being cleared of the shooting (though wanted in Florida for molestation). Johnny Mayhew's mother is arrested for illegal gun possession, publicly exposing the family, though Johnny was never the shooter.

person_rows.quote_or_scene: Maddy's uncle Patrick McCorkle goes to Buggesi's apartment after being tipped off by Mrs. McCorkle. SVU finds Patrick beating Buggesi unconscious. Patrick says Buggesi 'said he was sorry. That he was born with unnatural urges, he couldn't control himself.' Buggesi is hospitalized. Later: 'Buggesi was sitting in a dentist's chair at the time of the shooting' and 'There's an open warrant on him from Florida' (for actual molestation, not this shooting).
person_rows.notes: Buggesi is proven innocent of the SHOOTING (he has a dentist alibi), which is what SVU was investigating. He appears guilty of molesting Maddy (there's a Florida warrant and his own admission of 'unnatural urges'), but he did NOT commit the crime SVU was investigating (the school shooting). The uncle's assault is a direct consequence of SVU informing the family, leading to severe physical harm (beaten 'almost to death'). Severity 4 due to life-threatening injuries.

They find a .380 semiautomatic (mother's gun), test Johnny for gunshot residue, and arrest Mrs. Mayhew. Mrs. Mayhew protests: 'There is no way my Johnny shot those kids.' Though not arrested himself, the accusation is made publicly in his home with his mother present, and the wrong weapon caliber proves his innocence. Severity 2: public accusation witnessed by family, mother arrested, but no formal sanction against Johnny himself.

episode_summary.summary: Mike Mollinax was wrongfully convicted in 1972 for murdering his ex-wife Suzanne Mollinax and their baby in an arson fire. He served 34 years in prison before being exonerated by Jud Tierney's deathbed confession. Tierney revealed that his partner Jack Colino actually killed Suzanne when she threatened to expose their bank robberies, and Tierney then killed Colino to save the baby (Sheila). Mollinax's conviction was based solely on motive (prior threats while drunk) and circumstantial evidence. While in prison, Mollinax killed another inmate in self-defense during a race riot, complicating his release. He was ultimately pardoned by the governor on condition of pleading guilty to the prison murder with time served.

person_rows.quote_or_scene: MOLLINAX: 'September 17, 1971, I was sitting on a bar stool at McFadden's. Cops came in and arrested me for killing Suzanne and the baby. I told them I didn't do it. But nobody believed me.' 'I was a mean drunk back then. I didn't take it well when Suzanne threw me out.' 'One time I said I'd burn the place down if I ever caught her with another man.' 'It took the jury 20 minutes to convict.' FIN: 'The Mollinax case was closed in 1972. The ex-husband was convicted. Mike Mollinax, two counts of Murder Two, Arson in the First.'
person_rows.notes: Mollinax was convicted in 1972 for murdering his ex-wife Suzanne and their baby in an arson fire. He was actually innocent - Jack Colino committed the murders and Jud Tierney killed Colino. Mollinax served 34 years before exoneration. His conviction was based on motive (prior threats while drunk) and fleeing. He admits to being 'a mean drunk' who threatened to burn the house down, and beating up a girlfriend who then turned him in, but he did not commit the murders he was convicted of. The consequence is life-altering: 34 years wrongfully imprisoned, plus the complication of a prison killing in self-defense that nearly prevented his release.

episode_summary.source_notes: Primary plot involves kidnapped girls (Celia, Lori) held by John and Magda Plasky who impregnated them. Secondary plot: Simon Marsden (Olivia's brother) has children removed by Child Services after minor marijuana possession arrest.
episode_summary.summary: Simon Marsden is pulled over for a traffic violation with his fiancée Tracy and their two children. Officer finds one joint of marijuana (medical use for dental pain/appetite). Child Services removes children after home visit finds bruise on older child. Drug charge is dismissed due to unconstitutional search, but family court judge still denies return of children based on 'where there's smoke, there's fire' reasoning and Simon's past false rape accusation. In desperation, Simon and Tracy kidnap their own children from foster care, leading to arrest. Simon accepts plea deal requiring him to give up custody and live separately from family for 3 years in exchange for reduced charges.

person_rows.quote_or_scene: BAYARD ELLIS: 'Mr. Marsden has a history of contact with the police. He was a suspect in a rape case, jumped bail.' ELLIS: 'He was cleared on all counts. And those charges were the result of a personal vendetta by a now-disgraced police officer.'
person_rows.notes: Past rape accusation mentioned as part of family court proceeding. Was result of 'personal vendetta by a now-disgraced police officer.' Simon was cleared on all counts. Judge uses this cleared accusation as evidence ('where there's smoke, there's fire') to deny return of his children. The past false accusation continues to harm him in current custody case.

person_rows.quote_or_scene: MOTHER: 'The police questioned his story... They asked if I ever worried that Leo and her were too close.' MOTHER: 'So you thought your husband, your ex-husband, killed your daughter?' MOTHER: 'She was always a daddy's girl. I thought maybe something happened between them, and he covered it up.' LEO: 'Nobody would believe me. I have nightmares... I lost my marriage, my savings. I spent all my money on a PI, trying to find Celia.'
person_rows.notes: When daughter Celia disappeared 3 years prior, police questioned whether Leo had inappropriate relationship with her ('too close') and whether he killed her to cover it up. His wife believed police theory, leading to divorce. He spent all savings on private investigator trying to prove innocence by finding Celia. DNA proof that Celia is alive (and was kidnapped as he said) exonerates him 3 years later. Wife acknowledges: 'So all these years I've blamed Leo for something he didn't do?'

episode_summary.source_notes: Omar Pena falsely convicted in 2004 for rape of Ariel Baskins; spent 8 years in prison; conviction vacated after true rapist (Javier) commits copycat crime in 2013.
episode_summary.summary: Omar Pena was wrongfully convicted in 2004 for the rape and torture of Ariel Baskins based on a coerced confession containing a false detail (green vs. red scarf), victim misidentification, and witness misidentifications. He spent 8 years imprisoned. When the real rapist (Brazilian sailor Javier) committed an identical crime during Fleet Week 2013, DNA evidence and reinvestigation revealed Pena's innocence. The confession was obtained during a 9-hour interrogation where Detective Benson inadvertently fed Pena a false detail from a color-blind officer's evidence log. Six bar witnesses also misidentified Pena. Conviction vacated when true perpetrator arrested.

person_rows.police_conduct_quote: I told him that we had all kinds of evidence. I told him that he was going away no matter what. I broke him.
person_rows.quote_or_scene: Detective Benson: 'I forced a false confession... I broke him.' Judge: 'This court sincerely apologizes and will not allow you to be incarcerated for one minute longer... You're a free man, sir.'
person_rows.notes: Pena was subjected to 9-hour interrogation where Detective Benson used coercive tactics ('I told him we had all kinds of evidence... he was going away no matter what'). She inadvertently fed him false detail about green scarf (actually red) from color-blind officer's evidence log. Victim Ariel Baskins and 6 bar witnesses all misidentified him. He was convicted, sentenced to 315 years, served 8 years. Conviction vacated after DNA from 2013 copycat rape matched true perpetrator (Brazilian sailor Javier) to both crime scenes. Court formally apologized. Detective Benson acknowledged: 'I forced a false confession.' Severity 4: life-altering—8 years wrongful imprisonment.

episode_summary.summary: Christine Hartwell stages her own rape and kidnapping, falsely accusing delivery man Kevin Fahey. She later admits he raped her but evidence (video, testimony) shows consensual affair. Kevin is arrested, publicly tried, and spends time in custody. Previous delivery man Brad Hayes also publicly accused of affair during trial. Christine maintains innocence despite video evidence of consensual sex. Case ends in mistrial with 11-1 guilty vote. Both men face public exposure and legal consequences for consensual relationships Christine now claims were rape.

person_rows.police_conduct_quote: Did they tell you that you were looking at 25 years to life in prison? It came up.
person_rows.quote_or_scene: Detectives arrest Kevin at work: 'Police. I'll move the truck. I'm sorry. No, you won't. You're under arrest. Arrest for what? Rape and kidnapping.' Video evidence shows Christine saying 'You're a bad girl... Does your husband know how bad you are? Don't worry about him.' Christine later testifies: 'He's lying. He's making it up.'
person_rows.notes: Kevin arrested at workplace in front of coworkers. Faced 25-to-life, coerced into plea deal accepting 6 months for misdemeanor despite video evidence proving consensual relationship. Public trial exposed him. Christine fabricated entire rape claim after consensual 6-month affair. Exley cross: 'You cut a good deal... In exchange for your pornography-fueled fantasy.' Kevin has criminal record (armed robbery at 19) which prosecution weaponized against credibility.

person_rows.quote_or_scene: Exley: 'Earlier we heard testimony from Brad Hayes, a delivery man for PHX, and he testified that he had some sort of relationship with you. Why would he say something like that?' Christine: 'I have no idea. I barely remember him.' Exley presents delivery schedule showing 40-minute average visits vs 12-minute neighborhood average over 9 months. Christine: 'I heard he was making rude comments about me' (reason she stopped using PHX).
person_rows.notes: Brad Hayes called as defense witness at public trial. Christine claims 'I barely remember him' and 'absolutely not' to relationship question. However, she previously stopped using PHX delivery service 2 years prior because 'he was making rude comments about me'—suggesting preexisting allegation in community/neighborhood. Delivery records show pattern consistent with consensual relationship (40-min visits over 9 months). Public trial testimony exposes him to defamation as Christine denies everything under oath, calling him a liar. Implied innocent based on pattern matching Kevin's case and Christine's established pattern of false accusations.

person_rows.consequence_detail: arrested, publicly_accused, vigilante_attack, broken_hand, hospitalization, reputation_damage
person_rows.quote_or_scene: Stuart falsely claims: 'I heard him say, "You think you're special, bitch?" I recognized his voice.' Detectives arrest Henry: 'You tell him you're under arrest.' News report: 'Soho icon Henry Brazecki was beaten by vigilantes last night and hospitalized with a concussion and a broken hand.' Henry's alibis confirm: 'Three for three. person_rows.notes: Restaurant owner and community organizer falsely accused of being the West Soho serial rapist by Stuart, who planted hair evidence in Henry's car and lied about witnessing him rape Leslie. Henry was arrested, publicly exposed in media, and subsequently beaten by vigilantes (broken hand, concussion, hospitalization). His affairs with multiple women were exposed during investigation, damaging his marriage and reputation. Proven innocent when three alibi witnesses confirmed he was elsewhere during attacks. Stuart later confessed to being the actual rapist. Severity 4 due to vigilante attack causing serious injury plus extensive public/media exposure ruining reputation and marriage.

person_rows.police_conduct_quote: Benson: 'If I wasn't a cop, I'd smack you around too.' Detectives physically force him down: 'Get on the floor... you're breaking it!'
person_rows.quote_or_scene: Detectives publicly confront Andy at work in front of students. News footage: 'alleged rapist Andy Chen is attacked in broad daylight by five members of The Justice League.' episode_summary.summary: A man posing as donor father Colin Barnes contacts and seduces multiple donor daughters. Dr. Colin Barnes is initially suspected but proven innocent. Three teenage girls (Cate Avery, Ashley R., Melissa) are questioned and undergo lineups. Philip Kelly is briefly investigated as a suspect. The actual perpetrator is Sean Albers, who impersonated Barnes to seduce the girls and kidnap Barnes' biological daughter Taylor.

person_rows.quote_or_scene: Detectives approach Barnes at a public event while he's with his daughter Taylor. 'Dr. Barnes... these are detectives.' 'What's this about?' 'It's about your relationship with the daughters you fathered as a sperm donor.' His daughter witnesses this: 'Dad, what's wrong?' Later his daughter says: 'You're sick, daddy. How many kids do you have? A hundred? More? I could be dating one of my own brothers.' His wife also learns about his secret sperm donation through police questioning.
person_rows.notes: Barnes is accused publicly at a family event in front of his teenage daughter. Three victims (Ashley, Melissa, Cate) initially tell police they met with 'their donor father' and had sexual relationships. Barnes is brought in for questioning, subjected to lineups, and DNA testing. His family learns he was a sperm donor (a secret from his wife) and initially believes he raped his donor daughters. His daughter Taylor is devastated and leaves home. DNA later proves he did not have sex with any of the victims - Sean Albers impersonated him. Barnes receives no apology from police.

person_rows.quote_or_scene: Detectives track Kelly to North Jersey State Prison hospital wing where he works. 'Philip Kelly? NYPD.' Kelly responds: 'That's just great. What did I do now?' Detectives ask about his whereabouts and his relationship with Colin Barnes, clearly treating him as a suspect. Kelly provides alibi: 'Stuck at North Jersey State Prison, pulling a graveyard shift in the hospital wing.' When asked about Barnes' daughters: 'What are you talking about? Look, the only daughter I know is the teenager...'
person_rows.notes: Kelly is investigated as a suspect due to his vendetta against Barnes (Barnes fired him). Police confront him at his workplace (prison hospital) treating him as a suspect in the sexual assaults. He provides alibi which clears him. The questioning occurs at his place of employment, exposing him to potential workplace consequences. No apology shown.

episode_summary.summary: Two teachers are falsely accused of sexual misconduct with student Luca Gabardelli. Rick Simms is first accused, beaten by Luca's father in a staged gay-bashing, then arrested and publicly humiliated. When that accusation falls apart, Joanne Parsons is accused and arrested. Both are later cleared when it's revealed the actual abuser is teacher Natalie Relais, who manipulated Luca into fabricating accusations as cover.

person_rows.police_conduct_quote: You mean trying to take advantage of a vulnerable student... That would make him easy prey, right? / In my experience, boys this age, the stigma of homosexuality... don't usually make things like this up.
person_rows.quote_or_scene: Joanne called me into the headmaster's office. They said that a student had made an accusation against me. They wouldn't tell me [who or what]. In this system, to be accused is to be guilty. I left a job that I loved, my wife left me, and I got beat up. / Mr. Simms, your wife sent an attorney. person_rows.notes: Rick Simms is falsely accused by student Luca of exposing himself and propositioning him. School forces resignation without investigation. Luca's father has Simms beaten in staged gay-bashing attack. Simms is then arrested by SVU for sexual assault. Wife leaves him and sends divorce attorney. Eventually cleared when Luca recants and reveals actual abuser was Natalie Relais. Simms suffered job loss, marriage loss, violent assault, arrest, and public humiliation - all consequences of false accusation.

person_rows.police_conduct_quote: He described your bed, and your pillow, and your book of poetry. Can you tell me how he would know those details? / He also knew about the birthmark on your inner thigh. How would he know that?
person_rows.quote_or_scene: Joanne arrested at her home, bedroom searched, sheets bagged as evidence. Later: 'Joanne just tried to kill herself. Two hours ago, she filled her pockets with stones and walked into Prospect Park Lake.' Joanne: 'I never touched Luca. I would never touch a student... How could I say No, it's not Mr. Simms, it's Natalie? If I had told the truth... it would have destroyed her.'
person_rows.notes: Head of Upper School falsely accused by Luca after he recanted accusation against Simms. Luca and actual abuser Natalie fabricated accusation against Joanne as new cover story. Joanne arrested at home, bedroom searched with sheets seized, forced to expose birthmark. Attempted suicide by walking into lake with pockets filled with stones (Virginia Woolf-style). Was trying to protect Natalie (unrequited love interest) who was actually abusing Luca. Eventually cleared but suffered arrest, public humiliation, invasion of privacy, and near-death suicide attempt.

person_rows.notes: Pablo was questioned publicly on a rooftop with his current girlfriend Tiffany present, creating social embarrassment. He was cleared when he provided alibi and directed police to car service Nina used. No formal sanctions but public exposure in front of romantic partner qualifies as severity 2.

episode_summary.source_notes: Episode involves two child abduction cases: Wyatt Morris (current) and Hector Rodriguez (1999 cold case). Both connected to real estate developer family and arsonist Lewis Hodda.
episode_summary.summary: Seven-year-old Wyatt Morris is abducted from a subway platform. Investigation uncovers connection to 1999 disappearance of Hector Rodriguez, whose body is found buried in concrete in a building owned by Wyatt's grandfather. Lewis Hodda, an arsonist/troubleshooter for the Morris family, is arrested for both abductions. The episode also features auxiliary officer Stephen Lomatin, who becomes a suspect due to his obsessive focus on missing children cases but is cleared. Hector's father was wrongly blamed for 13 years for taking his son back to the Dominican Republic.

person_rows.quote_or_scene: BENSON: 'Hector Rodriguez, the Dominican kid... He was the exact same age. Missing boy, '99. Dad lost custody, took the kid back to the DR.' CRAGEN: 'We don't know that.' BENSON: 'The mother never saw her son again.' Later, BENSON: 'All these years we blamed his father.' Mother states: 'He doesn't have my son. Somebody else does.'
person_rows.notes: Father was blamed for 13 years (1999-2012) for allegedly taking his son Hector back to the Dominican Republic during custody dispute. Mother confirms they stayed in touch with father's family and he didn't have Hector. Squad assumed parental abduction; actual perpetrator was Lewis Hodda. Father separated from mother over religious differences (Pentecostal vs Catholic custody dispute). Consequence: lost contact with son, blamed by authorities and possibly community for 13 years.

person_rows.police_conduct_quote: MUNCH: 'You treated me like a skell instead of a cop.' LOMATIN: 'Like last time? You treated me like a skell instead of a cop.'
person_rows.quote_or_scene: CRAGEN: 'Officer Lomatin, I apologize. The sergeant isn't running this investigation.' ROLLINS finds evidence in his apartment: 'He's got children's clothes, surveillance photos, blond hair dye, and disguises.' Alibi confirmed: 'Drugstore in Brooklyn has him on video at the pharmacy window when Wyatt was snatched.'
person_rows.notes: Auxiliary officer who helped search for Hector in 1999 and Wyatt in 2012. Became suspect because: (1) found key evidence in both cases (Hector's lunch box in '99, Wyatt's cap in 2012), (2) sent anonymous letter to Hector's mother, (3) had obsessive archive of missing children cases with disguises/dye/clothes in his apartment. Cleared via drugstore video showing him picking up psychiatric medications (antidepressant, antianxiety, antipsychotic) at time of Wyatt's abduction. Was treated disrespectfully by Munch in both '99 and 2012 ('like a skell instead of a cop'). Cragen gave partial apology. Lomatin's pattern recognition about fires/abductions actually proved correct, vindicating his research. Consequence severity = 2 because he was publicly treated as suspect by multiple detectives, though no broader public exposure occurred.

episode_summary.summary: Sam Randall, a parolee, attempts to save Father Chris Shea from a violent assault and is wrongly arrested for carjacking and assault. Two neighborhood vigilantes beat the priest believing he was a pedophile. Sam is publicly arrested, remanded to custody through Christmas, and his parole is threatened. The detectives eventually prove Sam's innocence through security footage, forensics, witness statements, and Father Shea's testimony identifying Sam as his savior. Father Shea himself becomes a suspect due to being alone with a young girl but is later proven innocent. The actual molester is revealed to be Monsignor Menendez, who abused Angelica Rodriguez ten years prior.

person_rows.quote_or_scene: Sam arrested on street, taken to court, remanded to custody. His son Dante witnesses the arrest aftermath: 'Dad!' 'I'm sorry, Dante.' 'All Dante wanted for Christmas was his father.' Judge: 'Defendant has three prior convictions, is currently on parole, and is accused of a brutal assault against a clergyman who is still hospitalized. The people request remand. Granted.' Father Shea later testifies: 'This was a good samaritan. He pulled the others off of me. He saved me from them.'
person_rows.notes: Sam is a two-time felon on parole who intervened to save Father Shea from vigilantes. Despite being innocent, he was arrested publicly, remanded without bail through Christmas, and faced parole violation. His young son witnessed the aftermath. Father Shea, multiple detectives, security footage, and forensics all eventually proved his innocence. Released Christmas Eve by judge's conditional release.

person_rows.quote_or_scene: Detectives question Father Shea extensively about being alone with Sofia at night. Amanda: 'How well do you know her?' Fin references the 'little girl in your car.' Nick: 'So you gave him good reason to attack you? Mistakes. Is that what you're calling what you did to Angelica? A mistake?' Shea: 'What? No. No. You have it wrong.' Liv eventually acknowledges: 'The men who beat you up were wrong. And we were wrong. You didn't molest Angelica. You didn't molest Sofia.'
person_rows.notes: Father Shea was beaten by vigilantes who believed he was a pedophile because he was alone with a young girl. SVU detectives also suspected him throughout investigation due to circumstances and his transfer history. He was physically assaulted (beaten into a coma), publicly attacked as a 'chomo/short eyes,' and questioned as a suspect. Proven innocent - he had actually protected Angelica Rodriguez from Monsignor Menendez ten years prior and was transferred as punishment for breaking celibacy vows (Sofia is his biological daughter). The public beating and reputation damage qualify as harm even though police questioning was private.

episode_summary.source_notes: Derek Thompson convicted 17 years ago of raping his 6-year-old daughter Michelle. Michelle recants as adult, claims mother Audrey coached her to lie. episode_summary.summary: Derek Thompson spent 17 years in prison for raping his daughter Michelle based solely on her testimony at age 6. As an adult in recovery, Michelle recants, stating her mother Audrey (who had substance abuse issues) coached her to lie after a marital fight. Investigation reveals the lead detective Ted McCormack was having an affair with Audrey before the trial—they vacationed together in Key West during the pre-trial period. Neither McCormack nor Audrey disclosed their relationship. Derek maintained innocence for 17 years. Defense attorney at original trial received exculpatory letter from Michelle's teacher (stating Michelle said her mother made her lie) but never used it. Case granted federal habeas corpus and retrial. During retrial, Michelle testifies father is innocent, but under aggressive cross-examination by ADA O'Dwyer, she becomes confused and says 'I don't know.' Episode ends with verdict being read. Derek suffered severe consequences: 17 years imprisonment, sex offender registry, separation from children, and public stigma of being labeled a child rapist and incest perpetrator.

person_rows.quote_or_scene: Michelle (adult): 'Nothing happened that night. I swear.' / Derek: 'My wife lied, and she made Michelle lie.' / Michelle: 'I lied to the police. My mama said I had to keep saying it, or people would be mad at me for lying.' / Michelle's teacher wrote letter before trial stating Michelle disclosed her mother coached her to lie. / Detective McCormack had undisclosed affair with Audrey (Derek's wife) starting before trial, including Key West weekend trip. / Derek to Bayard Ellis: 'I've been asking myself that for the last 17 years' (why wife would frame him). / Michelle at retrial: 'No. No, he didn't [rape me].'
person_rows.notes: Derek Thompson is the central figure of wrongful conviction. He was accused of raping his 6-year-old daughter Michelle in 1998. The accusation originated from his wife Audrey after a marital fight, during which Audrey repeatedly questioned Michelle until the child said what her mother wanted to hear. Michelle told her first-grade teacher before trial that her mother made her lie—teacher sent letter to Detective McCormack and ADA O'Dwyer, but this exculpatory evidence was not effectively used at trial. Investigation 17 years later reveals Detective McCormack was having an affair with Audrey starting before the trial, including a Key West trip together, creating massive conflict of interest never disclosed. Derek maintained innocence throughout 17 years of incarceration, writing letters to his children. Adult Michelle recants multiple times, stating clearly her father never raped her. Derek refused plea deal that would have freed him because it required admitting guilt. At retrial, Michelle testifies father is innocent, though aggressive cross-examination by O'Dwyer causes momentary confusion. Consequences: 17 years in prison, sex offender registry, complete family separation, public stigma as child rapist and incest perpetrator, loss of children's entire childhoods. Severity 4 due to life-altering duration of imprisonment and permanent life damage. Episode ends mid-verdict so ultimate legal outcome unknown, but strong implication throughout is that Derek is innocent of a crime that never occurred.

episode_summary.summary: 15-year-old Lily Evans goes missing and is later found murdered. Initially, Diego (a fitness instructor she was sexting) is suspected, followed by Robby Marino (a roadie with prior sexual assault arrest). Both are cleared via DNA. The actual killer is Gary Ryan, identified through familial DNA matching via his deceased biological father Ray Marino. While Diego and Robby face interrogation, neither experiences significant public exposure or lasting consequence—Diego's arrest is work-related and brief; Robby's interrogation is contained to the precinct with only his lawyer brother aware. The episode focuses on the investigation rather than harm to the falsely accused.

Squad makes threatening statements about his sexting with 15-year-old. Later cleared when alibi confirms he was 'teaching X-treme Combat class all morning' at Brooklyn gym, far from crime scene.
person_rows.notes: Diego is arrested at his workplace (fitness studio) in front of colleagues/clients for suspected involvement in Lily's disappearance. His alibi (teaching class in Brooklyn all morning) is later confirmed, and 'Lily's not the only girl sexting him' suggests he's cleared. However, exposure is limited to the arrest scene at work—no media, no extended public pile-on shown. Severity 2: public accusation at workplace but no sustained consequence shown (firing, license loss, etc.).

person_rows.police_conduct_quote: She started flirting with you, right? She gave you that little smile... She takes off her jacket, her little t-shirt... She was taunting you... That made you mad... We all know what happened here, but we need to hear it from you. You tell us this, it's all over.
person_rows.quote_or_scene: Robby brought in for 6-hour interrogation. Detectives use coercive techniques: showing photos repeatedly despite his distress ('I can't look at that anymore. Please'), Reid-style false empathy ('She was taunting you... That made you mad'), leading him to near-confession ('Yeah, okay. She got in the van'). His brother George (a lawyer) is present but as subject of questioning, not as counsel. Right before formal confession, DNA clears him: 'The DNA on Lily's body doesn't match either of these brothers.'
person_rows.notes: Robby undergoes intensive coercive interrogation but DNA definitively clears him before charges. His only witness is his brother George (who eventually gives him up to police, creating family harm). However, exposure stays within interrogation room—no workplace, media, or public component shown. Severity 1: private interrogation with coercion but no public exposure or formal sanction. His prior sexual assault arrest (acquitted, complainant paid off) is mentioned but predates this episode's events.

episode_summary.summary: Lewis Hodda confesses to murdering Hector Rodriguez (1999) and kidnapping Wyatt Morris, but later recants and goes to trial. The trial focuses on Hector's murder. Defense attorney Lisa Hassler accuses SVU of coercing Hodda's confession and frames auxiliary officer Stephen Lomatin as an alternative suspect. The trial ends in a mistrial with a hung jury. Multiple people experience public exposure and harm from accusations during the episode.

person_rows.quote_or_scene: Defense attorney Lisa Hassler questions Lomatin on the stand: 'You'd often spoken with Hector, isn't that right?' 'How friendly?' 'Did you resent it when SVU Sergeant John Munch interrogated you about this case?' 'How long have you been taking anti-psychotic drugs?' 'Did you murder Hector Rodriguez?' Lomatin responds: 'I will not dignify that question with an answer, Your Honor.' Hassler: 'I'm not hearing a no. And so, there can only be only one logical conclusion.' Earlier in transcript: Lomatin states 'His own captain apologized to me. So did the other detectives.' regarding being questioned as suspect by Munch.
person_rows.notes: Lomatin was originally investigated by Munch as a suspect in 1999 (pictures of Hector found in his attic), but was cleared and received apologies from SVU. Defense attorney Hassler revives these accusations in open court during Hodda's trial, publicly suggesting Lomatin murdered Hector. The courtroom is full of press (established earlier), and Hector's mother is present. Lomatin becomes visibly distressed. This is a weaponized false accusation in a public forum causing reputational harm. Though Lomatin had mental health issues (anti-psychotic drugs mentioned), the transcript strongly implies he was innocent—he found evidence, was obsessed with solving the case, not committing it. SVU had apologized to him previously.

While she did rape two other students (Travis and Jordan), she did not kidnap Zach. Wrestling coach Donald Basinski used her photos (obtained from Jordan) to catfish Zach. Burnap is publicly arrested, interrogated, and exposed as a rapist before the real kidnapper is identified. She was innocent of the kidnapping/catfishing accusation but guilty of other crimes.

person_rows.police_conduct_quote: Listen, if you met up with Zach Foster, you need to tell us now. We're pulling the video from the AirTrain entrance and we're gonna put the two of you together... If something happens to Zach... the less likely you are to get a deal.
person_rows.quote_or_scene: Vermont ski lodge arrest: 'NYPD. Nobody move.' 'Where's Zach?' Arrested in front of new husband David during honeymoon. Later: 'Phoebe Burnap, you're under arrest.' Arraignment scene confirms media/photographers present: 'This is all over the news. There are photographers at the arraignment.'
person_rows.notes: Burnap IS guilty of raping Travis and Jordan (different students), but was INNOCENT of kidnapping/catfishing Zach Foster—the accusation for which she was arrested. She was publicly arrested at ski lodge with her new husband, interrogated coercively about Zach, charged with kidnapping/rape in Zach's case, and exposed in media. Her photos were stolen/used by Coach Basinski to catfish Zach. She eventually cut a deal after giving information about Basinski. This is a 'partially_involved' case: innocent of the ACCUSED crime (Zach kidnapping) but guilty of OTHER crimes (Travis/Jordan). Included because she suffered public exposure and arrest for a crime she didn't commit, even though she committed related crimes.

episode_summary.source_notes: This episode primarily involves a home invasion/hostage situation, not a sexual assault case. There is one mention of a 'push-in rapist' subplot where a suspect is arrested.
episode_summary.summary: The main plot involves Lt. Benson taken hostage during a home invasion. The subplot involves detectives arresting a man for being a 'push-in rapist' who assaulted multiple victims. The suspect claims innocence and threatens to sue, stating 'You got the wrong guy. Again.' His lawyer reinforces this, asking 'Who planted' the gun found on him. The detectives dismiss his claims and cite prints, DNA, and victim IDs. However, the suspect's repeated claims of wrongful arrest ('Again'), the lawyer's pointed questions, and the suspect's threat to sue suggest a pattern of false arrests. The episode does not provide clear resolution on whether he's actually guilty or innocent - the SVU team treats him as guilty, but the scripting suggests ambiguity.

person_rows.police_conduct_quote: Congratulations. You found another unarmed black man. / Nice work. (sarcastic from lawyer suggesting pattern of wrongful arrests)
person_rows.quote_or_scene: Suspect: 'You got the wrong guy. Again. I'm gonna sue your asses.' Detective: 'You left prints and DNA. Lab's gonna tie you to all those rapes.' Suspect: 'Here's what I know: lawyer.' Lawyer later: 'Congratulations. You found another unarmed black man. I suppose we should be grateful that you didn't shoot him.' Detective: 'He had a gun on him.' Lawyer: 'Did he? Who planted it?'
person_rows.notes: The episode strongly implies innocence through: (1) suspect's claim 'You got the wrong guy. Again' suggesting pattern of false arrests, (2) lawyer's pointed question 'Who planted it?' about the gun, (3) lawyer's sarcastic congratulations on finding 'another unarmed black man' suggesting SVU has a history of wrongful arrests of black men, (4) no resolution shown confirming guilt. The arrest occurs at victim's workplace (husband present, describes himself as being there when attack happened). While detectives claim DNA/prints will confirm, this is never shown, and the framing suggests the SVU team may be wrong. The 'Again' is particularly telling - this isn't the first time he's been wrongly accused. Severity 3 for arrest and racial profiling implications, though we don't see job loss or other consequences beyond the arrest itself.

The case involves a 'Cherry Pickers Club' where senior boys competed to have sex with virgins. Chris initially lied to police about sexual contact, then admitted to foreplay but denied rape. The case goes to trial with conflicting accounts: Abby says she told him to stop and slow down but he continued; Chris claims everything was consensual and he thought she was willing. The jury finds him not guilty of attempted rape and forcible touching but guilty of sexual misconduct in the first degree, requiring sex offender registry. Both families are devastated. While Chris faces consequences, he is NOT proven or strongly implied innocent - the jury convicted him of sexual misconduct. Therefore, no person rows are included as this does not meet the 'innocent person harmed by false accusation' criteria.

While Sean ultimately confesses to murdering Ashley Harper in the current timeline (making him guilty of THIS crime), he was definitively innocent of the ORIGINAL rape 16 years ago. The episode explicitly shows how the wrongful conviction and prison rape transformed him. Severity=4: life-altering imprisonment, repeated sexual assault, psychological destruction. episode_summary.summary: Quinn Berris is sexually assaulted by a masked attacker. She suspects Ray Wilson, a man who stalked her in college and served time for breaking into her dorm closet. He is later fired from his job. It's eventually discovered that retired Sergeant Tom Cole—Quinn's trusted friend and protector—planted the evidence and is the actual rapist. Ray Wilson qualifies as a falsely accused person who suffered public exposure and job loss as a direct consequence of the wrongful accusation.

person_rows.police_conduct_quote: Detectives confront him at work: 'We want to talk to you about Quinn Berris.' Later he states: 'I got fired yesterday' after 'you guys showed up' and 'barged into my restaurant and accused me of assaulting Quinn.'
person_rows.quote_or_scene: Ray Wilson is questioned by Detectives Rollins and Tutuola in his workplace kitchen in front of colleagues. He asks 'Can we go somewhere else?' indicating others are present. Later he tells detectives: 'I got fired yesterday. Till you guys showed up.' He also says they 'barged into my restaurant and accused me of assaulting Quinn.' His innocence is proven when surveillance shows Sergeant Tom Cole stealing Ray's cigarette butt to plant as evidence, and Ray's alibi (praying at church until 10:50 PM with video evidence) is confirmed.
person_rows.notes: Ray Wilson is a paroled sex offender (prior conviction for breaking into Quinn's college dorm closet). Despite his criminal history, he is proven innocent of THIS specific assault. Detectives question him publicly at his restaurant workplace (he asks to go elsewhere, indicating coworkers present). His DNA is found at the scene, but this is later proven to be planted evidence by the actual perpetrator, Tom Cole. Ray loses his job directly as a result of the public accusation. He has an airtight alibi (church with witnesses + video at 10:50 PM). Quinn initially misidentified him based on past trauma. The real rapist (Cole) deliberately framed Ray by stealing his cigarette butt before committing the assault.

person_rows.quote_or_scene: Detectives arrest Gabriel and interrogate him aggressively. Despite his DNA hair found in Theo's room being explained by prior relationship with mother (ended 2 months prior), he is held on weapons charges unrelated to kidnapping. Lawyer present throughout. Gabriel states: 'I don't know anything about the kid' and 'I've told you everything I know!'
person_rows.notes: Gabriel Norton is Nadine's ex-boyfriend with history of domestic violence (gave her black eye). DNA hair found in Theo's room from prior relationship. Detectives pursued him aggressively, arrested him fleeing out window, held him on gun/drug charges despite no evidence connecting him to kidnapping. He had angry texts about Theo but weak alibi. Ultimately proven uninvolved when Oscar/Gloria revealed as perpetrators. Held on weapons charge unrelated to kidnapping accusation.

person_rows.quote_or_scene: Benson to Fran: 'A lot of child abductions turn out to be orchestrated by the non-custodial parent. What are you saying? That I'm a suspect? I'm saying that we're gonna be going through your phone records, through your bank statements, and talking to the PI, and getting a warrant for any of the photos that he may have taken.'
person_rows.notes: Dr. Fran Conway is Theo's non-biological, non-adoptive co-parent (ex-wife of Nadine). She hired a PI to document Nadine's parenting for custody case. Detectives explicitly treat her as suspect ('A lot of child abductions turn out to be orchestrated by the non-custodial parent'), search her home/car, go through phone/bank records, obtain warrants for PI photos. Nadine also accuses her multiple times ('You accused her of kidnapping three times in the last hour'). Investigation remains primarily police-level but involves intrusive searches and explicit suspicion. Eventually cleared when Gloria/Oscar revealed as perpetrators. Exposure limited to police but investigation was thorough and accusatory.

episode_summary.source_notes: Episode focuses on Lawrence Hendricks, billionaire CEO accused of drugging and raping women. His grandson Eric is initially investigated but later cleared.
episode_summary.summary: Sarah Morrissey reports being raped at billionaire Lawrence Hendricks' birthday party. Eric is questioned at work (Avalon offices) in front of family members including aunt Cynthia and grandfather Lawrence. His father Larry also confronts detectives during interrogation. Eric faces workplace consequences as family members learn of accusation, though he is ultimately cleared when the real perpetrator (his grandfather) is exposed.

person_rows.quote_or_scene: Detectives question Eric at Avalon offices in presence of aunt Cynthia and grandfather Lawrence: 'Eric, you don't have to talk to these people.' person_rows.notes: Eric had consensual sex with Sarah but did not rape her. His grandfather Lawrence drugged and raped Sarah afterward. Eric is accused at his workplace (Avalon) in front of family members including his aunt (supervisor) and grandfather (company founder/CEO). His father removes him from grandfather's home. While Eric is 'partially_involved' (had consensual sex), he is innocent of the rape accusation. The public workplace confrontation in front of family/colleagues constitutes severity 2 exposure even without formal job action.

He's raping me!' causing Luke to shoot and kill Trey. Nicole maintained the rape claim through initial police interviews and trial testimony before changing her story. person_rows.quote_or_scene: Nicole looked at Luke and screamed 'Help! He's raping me!' causing Luke to shoot Trey. Nicole later admits on stand: 'Trey Franklin and I were in the kitchen having sex. Then Luke walked in on us and shot his friend in the head.' She fabricated the rape claim to protect herself and manipulate her son.

The accusation was knowingly false - Nicole was the sexual predator, not Trey. This is the most extreme consequence possible: death directly caused by a fabricated accusation.

Unable to cope with the trauma and confused about memory, she falsely identifies Gary Cook, a misogynist online troll who was at the fight club that night. person_rows.quote_or_scene: Detectives bring Cook in for questioning after Beth identifies him from a photo. He is arrested attempting to flee. Cook: 'I hit her with a firm and respectful handshake.' He attended the fight club and shook Beth's hand outside. Beth falsely identified him as her rapist from a photo lineup. He was arrested when he ran from detectives. His alibi was ironclad with multiple witnesses and sign-in sheet placing him 50 blocks away at 4:50am. Surveillance footage confirmed he walked away from Beth after handshake. While he faced arrest and questioning, there is no evidence of public exposure beyond police interaction or material harm beyond the arrest itself.

episode_summary.source_notes: Transcript from Season 18, Episode 15: Know It All
episode_summary.summary: Jennifer Knowles is murdered and initially attributed to a serial killer (the Second Avenue Strangler). SVU discovers her actual killer was her boyfriend David Willard, a data-mining tech CEO who blackmailed witnesses and experts to cover his tracks. Two people are falsely accused with public exposure: Dr. Colin Bennett (rope expert blackmailed into falsifying evidence) and ADA Rafael Barba (blackmailed into recusing himself). The serial rapist/killer confessed to Jennifer's murder despite not committing it.

person_rows.quote_or_scene: Bennett: 'I got a call. There was no name. It was untraceable... Change my report. Say the ropes don't match. In case anyone checked, get rid of the rope.' Benson finds Bennett with a gun contemplating suicide: 'My work was my life. And now I can't go back, ever... I thought I could make up for my one mistake through my work, but when everyone knows everything, how can one ever really forgive and forget?'
person_rows.notes: Bennett was blackmailed by Willard into falsifying rope evidence. Willard hacked Bennett's emails and discovered 'something embarrassing and wrong' from his past. Bennett contemplated suicide, saying his career was over. While the initial 'accusation' against Bennett was implied professional misconduct (changing his report), the real harm was being blackmailed into destroying his own credibility and career. This caused life-altering harm (severity 4) including suicide attempt. The exposure was primarily to law enforcement, but the consequence was career-ending.

person_rows.quote_or_scene: Barba to Benson: 'There was nothing I could do. I had to recuse myself... Willard must have hacked my bank account, tracked down Ashtonja... I told [the DA] everything. We might've seen our last case together.' Barba explains he gave money to Ashtonja Abreu (daughter of a deceased witness) and Willard tried to make it look like payment for sex.
person_rows.notes: Willard hacked Barba's bank records, discovered he was giving money to Ashtonja Abreu, and fabricated an accusation that it was payment for sex (sex trafficking/corruption). Willard used this to blackmail Barba into recusing himself from the case. Barba had to report everything to the DA and faces potential career consequences ('We might've seen our last case together'). The implied accusation was paying for sex/corruption. While not explicitly stated as a formal charge, the blackmail forced professional consequences and career risk. Severity 3 for material professional sanction and career jeopardy.

episode_summary.summary: Congressman Luke Bolton is falsely accused of involvement in a child sex trafficking ring through hacked emails and planted child pornography. The false accusations originate from a fake news website ('The Endless Truth') and lead to public exposure, threats, and ultimately violence. The investigation reveals Bolton was framed by hackers, but the fake news leads to discovery of an actual (unrelated) sex trafficking ring. Restaurant owner Mr. Lee is also falsely implicated and suffers business consequences and threats from believers of the conspiracy theory.

person_rows.quote_or_scene: Bolton: 'according to the Internet, I'm a customer of an underage sex trafficking ring run out of a Chinese restaurant called the Coral Dragon.' Later: 'When my email was hacked, I thought it was routine harassment, business as usual these days, but this... they can plant things remotely on people's computers.' Final scene: Bolton shot at restaurant while with his daughter by someone who believed the conspiracy theory.
person_rows.notes: Bolton was framed via hacked emails and planted child pornography on his computer. A hacker (Raj) was paid to do this by unknown parties, possibly foreign intelligence. The fake news website 'The Endless Truth' spread the accusations online. Bolton came to SVU voluntarily to clear his name. Investigation proved the material was planted while he was in Washington. Despite SVU's public statement clearing him, the website continued accusations. Episode ends with Bolton being shot at the restaurant while trying to publicly demonstrate it was safe, showing life-altering physical harm to him and trauma to his daughter.

person_rows.quote_or_scene: Lee: 'I've been getting death threats. My employees are getting death threats.' Later: 'This is out of control. Who's gonna come eat here now?' And: 'That man came in with a gun. He saw the Congressman with his daughter. He shouted at him... He shot him. Is this ever gonna stop?'
person_rows.notes: Lee's restaurant was falsely accused of being a front for child sex trafficking based on conspiracy theories about coded language in Bolton's emails and the restaurant's logo. Malcolm Barnstable entered with a rifle demanding to see the basement where girls were supposedly held. SVU investigation found no basement and no trafficking. Despite SVU's public statement clearing the restaurant, online harassment continued. Lee suffered ongoing death threats, employee harassment, and business losses. The conspiracy theory ultimately led to a shooting at his restaurant. SVU provided some security but offered only partial acknowledgment of the harm.

person_rows.police_conduct_quote: Rollins: 'That's a confession. Illegal child pornography. Plus, you were doing more than looking.' Carisi: 'Well, it looks like your sins aren't all in the past, hmm?' Fleming: 'I can't go back to jail. My business, my children...' Carisi: 'It's a little late to think about that.'
person_rows.quote_or_scene: Fleming: 'Coral Dragon? I sold 'em dishes and cutlery, but I lost the account more than ten years ago.' Later investigation finds child pornography on his computer. Fleming: 'I was only looking... I can't help myself... My wife... this will destroy her. I can't go back to jail. My business, my children...' Then: 'Fin: This fool just tried to shoot himself.'
person_rows.notes: Fleming was initially investigated because 'The Endless Truth' connected him to the Coral Dragon restaurant and noted his 30-year-old statutory rape conviction. He was innocent of the Coral Dragon trafficking conspiracy. However, investigation of his computer revealed actual child pornography possession and recent contacts with a real (unrelated) sex trafficking ring. He is 'partially_involved' because he is innocent of the ACCUSED offense (Coral Dragon conspiracy) but guilty of other sex crimes (CP possession, soliciting minors). The interrogation was coercive and threatening. Fleming attempted suicide during the sting operation. While he did commit crimes, the harm (suicide attempt) was a consequence of being falsely connected to the Coral Dragon conspiracy, then investigated and confronted about actual crimes in a coercive manner.

Hector's alibi: home with wife Soledad (who backs him up). ADA acknowledges 'no jury's gonna convict based on two strands of hair' and 'Without Yusef, it's meaningless.' Released for insufficient evidence. His consistent denials, lack of forensics, and prosecutors' acknowledgment of weak case strongly imply innocence. Public arrest at workplace, arraignment, media coverage = severity 3. Episode ends with Hector being taken hostage, suggesting he is viewed as wrongly accused by community.

episode_summary.summary: Laurel Linwood reports being raped after being found at a museum. Investigation reveals she met Greg Harvey at a bar and went to his apartment, where she killed him with scissors. Through interrogation, it emerges Laurel fabricated memories of childhood sexual abuse by her father - the actual victim was her sister Leah. Laurel's false memories and killing of Harvey stemmed from jealousy that her father never abused her like he did Leah. Greg Harvey was innocent of rape; Laurel killed him in a displaced rage at her father. The accusation against Harvey (posthumously) and the childhood sexual abuse dynamics are central, but Harvey's innocence only becomes clear through Benson's interrogation revealing Laurel's fabricated narrative.

Laurel killed him because he reminded her of her father (same aftershave, same watch brand) and she displaced her rage about never being chosen for abuse onto Harvey.

However, he is accused of rape to police/hospital, investigated as a rapist, and dies as a direct consequence of a false accusation. His innocence is proven through Benson's interrogation revealing Laurel's fabricated memories and confession to premeditated murder. The harm (death) is severity 4. Exposure was police_only since he died before any public revelation, but the accusation directly caused his death.

person_rows.notes: Carlos was 18 when arrested in 2003 for murdering his mother Nydia and 13-year-old sister Jacinta. He confessed after Detective Monte threatened him with death penalty ('sayonara syringe'). He had an alibi (was at Plumb Beach with Ricardo Torres) but couldn't reveal it because he was gay and feared prison rape/murder if inmates learned this. Served 16 years before DNA exonerated him in 2019. His mother and sister were actually killed by maintenance worker Tim Stanton. DA Keane built his career on this wrongful conviction. Carlos describes ongoing trauma in prison, including fear of sexual assault ('getting bitched out until I got the bug, like Ricky'), inability to learn where his family was buried, and PTSD/depression. Consequence severity 4: life-altering imprisonment, permanent trauma, loss of 16 years, exposure to violence/rape risk in prison.

person_rows.notes: Ricardo Torres was 15 when Detective Monte coerced him into a false confession and convinced him to testify against Carlos Hernandez with false promises of leniency ('man two and out in 15'). Served 15 years. Contracted HIV/full-blown AIDS while imprisoned. Released approximately 2018, died in 2019 shortly before the case was reopened. Before death, wrote letter to Carlos apologizing for lying and putting him away. Moms Baker scattered his ashes and described how he 'cried on my shoulder' about lying on Carlos 'to save his own skin.' Died of AIDS contracted as direct consequence of wrongful imprisonment. Consequence severity 4: death from AIDS contracted in prison, 15 years lost, guilt/trauma, never saw exoneration.

He is handcuffed, arrested on outstanding warrants (BLM protest-related), and treated as a suspect in a sexual assault case he had nothing to do with. The arrest is filmed and goes viral. Joe Murphy is later identified as the actual perpetrator but is acquitted by a grand jury skeptical of police credibility after the wrongful arrest. Jayvon loses his job when his NA attendance becomes public, and Captain Benson is investigated by IAB for racial bias.

Captain Benson later apologizes privately but Jayvon rejects it. DA pursues charges against Colleen Reynolds for false report. episode_summary.summary: Ceranda Zajmi, a 17-year-old girl, is murdered. Lonnie Liston, a Black teen on the sex offender registry living in an SRO dubbed the 'pedo motel,' becomes the primary suspect. Detectives question him aggressively, violate his parole, and surveillance him. Community outrage and vigilante violence lead to Lonnie being tortured, mutilated, and murdered by vigilantes who believe he killed Ceranda. Later, DNA evidence proves Lonnie was innocent—the real killer was Sam Johnson, hired by parole officer Roy Eastman to frame Lonnie. Lonnie had a secret alibi (meeting his underage ex-girlfriend) that he couldn't reveal without violating parole. The episode illustrates compounding harms: false public accusation, detective coercion/threats, media/community exposure, and ultimately lynching of an innocent man.

And if I were you, I wouldn't go out there.' / 'Look, Black teen with a white girlfriend? The jury would never believe me.' Fin: 'Uh-huh. Look, man, we get it, all right? Ceranda's your type... Young, cute, white. You know, you try to hit on her, she says no, then you make your play anyway.' / 'I don't believe you. And those people out there? They don't believe you, either.' / Fin (to Carisi): 'I assumed Lonnie was guilty 'cause he was in that rat trap... I checked his single-bust record, and I made him for dirty... because of me, another innocent kid gets lynched.'

Boss Zamir fires him after anonymous tip about registry. Community protests outside motel calling residents 'sex offenders.' Vigilantes Eduardo, Louie, and Juan torture, strangle, sexually mutilate, and burn Lonnie alive. DNA later proves Lonnie innocent—real killer was Sam Johnson, hired by PO Roy Eastman to frame Lonnie. Lonnie's parents reveal he had alibi (secret meeting with underage ex-girlfriend McKenna) but couldn't tell police without violating parole. Fin's reflection: 'I assumed Lonnie was guilty... I made him for dirty... another innocent kid gets lynched for it.'
person_rows.notes: Lonnie is the central false suspect. He was on the sex offender registry for a prior 'Romeo and Juliet' statutory case (turned 18, girlfriend 15, her stepfather Roy Eastman forced prosecution). Anonymous caller tips off his boss about registry status. Detectives publicly question him at work, threaten parole violation, surveil him. Boss fires him. Community protestors demonize SRO residents. Lonnie is tortured, strangled, sexually mutilated, and burned alive by vigilantes inspired by community activist Elvis Baktashi's rhetoric. DNA evidence later proves Sam Johnson (hired by Eastman to frame Lonnie) killed Ceranda. Lonnie had alibi (met ex-girlfriend McKenna at Penn Station during break) but couldn't reveal it without violating parole. Severity 4: murdered. Police conduct included repeated threats, racial profiling assumptions, refusal to believe denials. Fin later expresses remorse for presuming guilt. Episode depicts compounding systemic failures: registry stigma, police coercion, community vigilantism, and ultimately lynching of an innocent Black teenager.

He was later proven innocent via surveillance footage showing him in Tompkins Square Park during the crime. The interrogation also led to disclosure of his abuse to his parents, though this was ultimately necessary and handled sensitively by Detective Bruno.

Father Alberto was threatened and fled police in terror before being killed in struggle with Gomez.

person_rows.notes: Miguel Pinto's DNA was found on murder victim Ana Machado. He was arrested and questioned multiple times. Later proven that Lieutenant Gomez hired sex worker Charisse Johnson to steal used condom from Miguel after his cousin allegedly hired her for him. Gomez then planted Miguel's DNA on Ana's body to frame him. Miguel cleared when investigation revealed Gomez was actual killer. ADA Price's team confirms 'Guy was in Staten Island' with alibi. Working theory established that 'somebody framed him.'

Later Benson realizes: 'the fear that I saw in Father Alberto's eyes' and 'I think that he sent somebody to threaten Father Alberto the morning that he shot him.' person_rows.notes: Father Alberto ran Catholic shelter. Squad suspected him based on witness seeing him with crying woman late at night in his room. When Benson and Gomez arrived to question him, he fled in terror. Church was 'pretty banged up' beyond what ICE raid would cause. During struggle over Gomez's gun in catacombs, Father Alberto said 'I can't' when ordered to drop weapon—both men's hands on gun when it discharged. Father died. Later investigation reveals Gomez (actual killer) sent someone to threaten Father Alberto before the confrontation, causing him to flee. Benson realizes Father was innocent victim threatened by Gomez. Captain acknowledges 'professional courtesy' issue around testing Father's DNA against evidence, implying she later understood he was innocent. Episode strongly implies Father was murdered by Gomez to silence potential witness.

episode_summary.summary: Dr. Gretchen Stewart is raped and assaulted in her office. Anthony Fierro, a patient with DV history and ketamine paranoia, is initially suspected. SVU confronts him on a highway; he pulls a gun and commits suicide. Later investigation reveals he was at his hotel during the attack (confirmed by surveillance and receipts). The actual perpetrator is Ted Schramm, who attacked three therapists. Fierro's wife had taken out a restraining order after couples therapy with Dr. Stewart helped her leave him.

person_rows.quote_or_scene: Highway pursuit scene: Velasco and Fin pursue Fierro in traffic. 'Both: Gun! Stay in your car! Stay down!' Fierro says 'I didn't go near her!' before pulling gun and jumping, later dying. Wife's statement confirms hotel alibi: 'At the hotel, I assume. I have the receipt.' Fin reports: 'Anthony Fierro is not the man who attacked you' confirmed by 'camera footage confirming that he was there the entire night of your attack.'
person_rows.notes: Fierro was Dr. Stewart's patient in couples therapy. His wife took out restraining order after therapy. He had DV arrests and ketamine-induced paranoia. Squad pursued him based on threat history and access to victim. High-speed highway confrontation witnessed by multiple civilian drivers. He denied involvement ('I didn't go near her!') before pulling gun and jumping from elevated highway, dying from impact. Later proven innocent via hotel surveillance footage and purchase receipts showing he was at hotel entire night of attack. Severity 4: death (suicide) directly caused by accusation and pursuit.

episode_summary.summary: SVU investigates a fertility clinic bombing that destroys evidence in a rape case. Dr. Ila Mukherjee is found murdered. Initial suspects include rape suspect Ted Simons, antinatalist activist Kirk Young, and the victim's estranged husband Chris Clemente. All are cleared. The actual killer is revealed to be Mark Olson, Mukherjee's own divorce lawyer, who killed her to prevent being exposed for malpractice and to collect on fraudulent liens.

person_rows.police_conduct_quote: Detectives falsely claim they already have his DNA from fertility clinic and that Detective Bruno is testing it, using deception to coerce confession. Later they trick him into drinking water to steal DNA from bottle.

Later interrogate using false evidence claims: 'Detective Bruno's already testing that sample as we speak.' He initially denies knowing Katie Wilkins, then under pressure admits 'Maybe I did sleep with the girl.' Arrested and sent to Rikers. Later cleared when murder investigation reveals he had nothing to do with bombing.
person_rows.notes: Simons is accused of rape (separate case) and bombing. He admits to sexual contact with Katie Wilkins under coercive interrogation but is innocent of the bombing. SVU publicly confronts him at work, arrests him, and uses deceptive tactics. Tagged as 'partially_involved' because he may have committed the rape but is innocent of the bombing charges that drove the public workplace confrontation and arrest in this episode. The bombing accusation is what brings public workplace exposure and arrest shown on-screen.

person_rows.notes: Clemente is questioned at his workplace as murder suspect but exposure remains private (no colleagues shown present during accusation). He is cleared when forensics don't match. Included because detectives arrive at his job site to accuse him, creating at minimum workplace disruption and implied stigma, qualifying as severity 2 public exposure at work even without confirmation of wider knowledge.

person_rows.quote_or_scene: Young is pursued and tackled at public protest at Astor Place. Arrested for murder of Dr. Mukherjee. Interrogated where Benson states 'I don't think you care about activism... I think that you like 'em young. I think that you're in it not for the cause, but you're in it for the girls.' person_rows.notes: Young is innocent of the Mukherjee murder (the crime SVU is investigating in this episode) and is publicly arrested at a protest. He is actually guilty of murdering Autumn Diaz but that's a separate crime. For the Mukherjee investigation, he's a false suspect who is publicly arrested and humiliated before being cleared by alibi. The public arrest at the protest and the degrading interrogation about being a sexual predator qualify as public exposure and harm.
